Fill in the blanks.
explanation: Despite facing massive anti-regime protests in 2011, neither al-Khalifa dynasty in Bahrain nor Bashar al-Assad in Syria lost their hold on power until today. In this sense, unlike the cases of Egypt, Tunisia, Libya, and Yemen, governing coalitions in Bahrain and Syria remained more or less intact in the course of the uprisings. Moreover, both regimes still enjoy great support from their traditional power bases both inside and outside their countries.

text: Which of the below is not a cause of the "weak state" in Yemen and Libya?

options.B: Geographies that are extremely difficult to govern
options.C: Inter-regional and intra-societal differences within each country
options.D: Failure of the construction of national identity.
options.E: Both regimes having rentier natures rather than taxation.

explanation: Roots of weak state structures are threefold: First of all, both countries are located in geographies that are extremely difficult to govern. Secondly, there are significant inter-regional and intra-societal differences within each country that limits the construction of national identity. Lastly, both regimes have rentier natures.

text: Which country listed below is considered to be the starting point of Arab uprising?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “Evolution of 2011 Uprisings in the Arab World” section.
The starting point of the Arab Uprisings was Tunisia, which had been ruled by Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali since 1987.

text: Which word below had initially meant to shudder, toshiver, to shake off, to recover, to recuperate; but gained a new meaning:"resistance",that directly define the Palestinian civil against Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in 1987?
explanation: If your answer is wrong, please review the “Introduction” section.

text: Which term below started as referring to the neoliberalization of the Egyptian economy and gained the meaning adoption of neo-liberal programs in Arab countries?
explanation: Egypt became the first country in the Arab world to adopt the open-door policy, infitah in Arabic, for domestic or foreign private investment. Then, many Arab countries followed suit.

text: Who was the president in Tunisia when the Arap uprising began?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “Evolution of 2011 Uprisings in the Arab World” section.
The starting point of the Arab Uprisings was Tunisia, which had been ruled by Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali since 1987. Under the rule of Ben Ali, Tunisian people had been experiencing widespread corruption, high unemployment, and immense political repression

text: Who was the ruler in Yemen when the massive protests took place on 27 January 2011?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “Evolution of 2011 Uprisings in the Arab World” section.
Yemen had been under the highly personalized rule of Ali Abdullah Saleh since 1978. On 27 January 2011, just two days after the outbreak of the Egyptian uprising, massive protests against poverty and corruption took place in the Yemeni capital Sana’a, and quickly spread to other major cities throughout February.

text: Which of the following is an alternative name for the Ansarullah Movement?
explanation: If your answer is wrong, please review the “State Collapse and Civil War in Libya and Yemen” section.

text: Which is the only Arab country where a successful transition based on a policy of reconciliation between different actors has emerged without a coup, civil war or international intervention?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “'Orderly' Transition in Tunisia and Egypt during the Post-revolutionary Process” section.
Tunisia has been the only Arab country where a successful “sui generis” transition has emerged, based on a policy of reconciliation between different actors, primarily Islamists and secularists, without any coups, civil war or international intervention.

text: What year did the Yemeni Civil War begin?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “State Collapse and Civil War in Libya and Yemen” section.
The Yemeni Civil War started in 2015, after the capture of the capital Sanaa by Houthi rebels in the north.

text: In what year did the Libyan Civil War begin?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “State Collapse and Civil War in Libya and Yemen” section.
The Libyan Civil War started in 2014 with the launch of Operation Dignity by forces loyal to Khalifa Hafter to grab power.

text: Who was the leader of Syria when large anti-government protests were held in Damascus and Aleppo on March 15, 2011?
explanation:
If your answer is wrong, please review the “Evolution of 2011 Uprisings in the Arab World” section.
Bashar al-Assad has ruled Syria since the death of his father and former president Hafez al-Assad in 2000. Although Bashar first appeared as a young reformist leader, his reform initiatives were soon suppressed by the old guards in the military and the ruling Baath Party.

text:
Anti-regime protests in the Arab uprisings began in ....... in 2010.
Which of the following correctly fills in the blank above?
explanation: Initially, it was in Tunisia where the first Arap uprisings started in 2010.

text: What are the common factors of the roots of the Arab uprisings?

options.A: The education system, wish for revolution, environmental factors
options.B: The economic gap between the richest and the poorest, the minority problems
options.C: The socio-economic and political factors, the impact of social media
options.D: The psychological factors and the wish to modernize
options.E: Pollution of the air and water and geo-political factors

explanation: Some common factors can be divided into three sub-categories as follows: socio-economic reasons, political factors, and the impact of social media.

text: Which regimes could remain tight and unshakeable after the Arab uprisings?
explanation: Unlike the cases of Yemen and Libya, Bahraini and Syrian regimes remained tight and steadfast.

text:
The Tunisian transition process to democracy remained stable based on .............
Which of the following correctly fills in the blank above?

options.B: agreements with the people of Tunisia
options.C: a reconciliation policy between the different political actors.

explanation: The Tunisian transition process to democracy remained stable based on a reconciliation policy between the different political actors.

text: How did Yemen and Libya differ from other countries that experienced anti-regime uprisings?

options.A: Their leaders gave up power only after the foreign intervention.
options.B: The uprisings in these countries ended up in total democracy.
options.C: The leaders never gave up the power of administration even after the uprisings.
options.D: They could handle the uprisings better because they were more prosperous than others.
options.E: There was a unified vision among the policymakers.

explanation: Their leaders left the power only after a foreign intervention.

text: Which Arab country below has had a successful transition after the uprising based on reconciliation between the Islamists and the seculars, without a coup, civil war, or international intervention?
explanation: Tunisia has been the only Arab country where a ‘sui generis’ successful transition emerged based on a reconciliation policy between different actors, mainly Islamists and the seculars, without any coups, civil wars, or international intervention.

text:
In Egypt, Morsi caused distress both on the liberal-seculars and on the army because they thought .......
Which of the following correctly fills in the blank above?

options.A: the Muslim Brotherhood intended to rule the country based on Sharia law.
options.B: his government provided too much freedom for women's rights.
options.C: the government provided too much liberty for the non-Muslim population.
options.D: Morsi allocated much more money to the army than planned before.
options.E: Morsi practiced nepotism by bringing his friends and relatives into powerful positions.

explanation: After coming into power in 2012, the brotherhood-led government took some critical steps, which led to a confrontation with both the secular-liberals and the army. First of all, the new constitution drafted by the Constituent Assembly did not provide legal protection to the believers of non-Abrahamic religions and hesitated to guarantee gender equality in a secular sense. This attitude of the new regime put secularists in doubt that the Muslim Brotherhood intended to rule the country based on Sharia law.

text: What happened after the rulers of Libya and Yemen fell as a result of the uprisings?

options.A: The new regimes in both countries brought stability and prosperity to the region.
options.B: Both countries now have democratic regimes, which obey universal human rights.
options.C: These regimes eventually resulted in total state collapse and internationalized civil wars.
options.D: These regimes eventually resulted in more powerful state institutions.
options.E: These regimes eventually resulted in more prestigious states at the international level.

explanation: The fall of Gaddafi and Saleh did not result in an orderly transition to democracy in Libya and Yemen. On the contrary, the fall of these regimes eventually resulted in total state collapse and internationalized civil wars, which still undermines the security and stability of the MENA region.

text:
The Bahrain administration could survive the Arab uprising because of the military intervention of the Gulf Commission Countries (GCC). Saudi Arabia, as the leading GCC country, perceived the anti-regime protests in Bahrain as a major threat.......
Which of the following correctly fills in the blank above?

options.A: which may decrease oil prices and may harm their economy.
options.B: which can increase the power of terrorist organizations.
options.C: that can spread Saudi Arabia and other neighbors in the Gulf.
options.D: that can potentially increase the Iranian influence in the region.
options.E: that can potentially decrease the importance of the Gulf Commission.

explanation: GCC, and its leading country Saudi Arabia were afraid of the fact that Iran may potentially increase its influence in Bahrain.

text: How did the Assad regime gain control in the Syrian war in 2015?

options.A: Russia directly intervened on the side of the regime in 2015.
options.B: The United States directly intervened on the side of the regime in 2015.
options.C: The terrorist organizations such as PKK-affiliated YPG were defeated by international organizations.
options.D: Assad became very powerful by being backed by the strong Syrian army.
options.E: Assad was supported by other Arab countries, such as Saudi Arabia and others.

explanation: The turning point of the war was the direct military intervention of Russia on the side of the regime in 2015.
